commit_message:
Database layer for Artifact Repository

Adds a Data Model (Tables: Artifact, ArtifactDependecy, ArtifactTag,
ArtifactProperty, ArtifactBlob, ArtifactBlobLocation), Migrations and DB
API for SQLAlchemy. Adds wrappers for simple and registry DB drivers.

Adds appropriate unittests to DB API tests and to migration tests.

Implements-blueprint: artifact-repository

Co-Authored-By: Alexander Tivelkov <ativelkov@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Mike Fedosin <mfedosin@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Inessa Vasilevskaya <ivasilevskaya@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ia491a58956101a1c40f1bca95cd9efe432f13dce

added_lines: from sqlalchemy import Numericclass Artifact(BASE, GlanceBase): __tablename__ = 'artifacts' __table_args__ = (Index('ix_artifact_name', 'name'), Index('ix_artifact_type', 'type_name'), Index('ix_artifact_state', 'state'), Index('ix_artifact_owner', 'owner'), Index('ix_artifact_visibility', 'visibility')) id = Column(String(36), primary_key=True, default=lambda: str(uuid.uuid4())) name = Column(String(255), nullable=False) type_name = Column(String(255), nullable=False) type_version_prefix = Column(BigInteger, nullable=False) type_version_suffix = Column(String(255), nullable=True) version_prefix = Column(BigInteger, nullable=False) version_suffix = Column(String(255), nullable=True) description = Column(Text) visibility = Column(String(32), nullable=False) state = Column(String(32), nullable=False) owner = Column(String(255), nullable=False) published_at = Column(DateTime, nullable=True) class ArtifactTag(BASE, GlanceBase): __tablename__ = 'artifact_tags' __table_args__ = (Index('ix_artifact_tags_artifact_id', 'artifact_id'), Index('ix_artifact_tags_artifact_id_tag_value', 'artifact_id', 'value')) id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False, default=lambda: str(uuid.uuid4())) artifact_id = Column(String(36), ForeignKey('artifacts.id'), nullable=False) artifact = relationship(Artifact, backref=backref('tags')) value = Column(String(255), nullable=False) class ArtifactProperty(BASE, GlanceBase): __tablename__ = 'artifact_properties' id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False, default=lambda: str(uuid.uuid4())) artifact_id = Column(String(36), ForeignKey('artifacts.id'), nullable=False) artifact = relationship(Artifact, backref=backref('properties')) string_value = Column(String(255)) int_value = Column(Integer) numeric_value = Column(Numeric) bool_value = Column(Boolean) text_value = Column(Text) models = ( Image, ImageProperty, ImageMember, Artifact, ArtifactTag, ArtifactProperty) models = (Image, ImageProperty, Artifact, ArtifactTag, ArtifactProperty)

commit_message:
Allow PYTHONHASHSEED to be random

This was done once before but some sphinx extensions for WSME caused
issues. Those may be fixed now.

Change-Id: I8258ccd6746f936d552ff2b24e630b4ab033544f
Closes-Bug: #1348818

subject: Add support for DB2 datastore in Trove
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-13 18:17:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/82d905641a9970ae548a72071b83d05fa1201163', 'message': 'Add support for DB2 datastore in Trove

The following features have been implemented in this patchset:
- Launch
- Reboot
- Terminate
- Resize Volume
- Create/Delete/List database(s)
- Create/Delete/List user(s)
- List Access
- Included unit tests for the different methods

Change-Id: If95686dd37d2730a4d00f4010fa8515f33a8e337
Implements: blueprint db2-plugin-for-trove
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-13 18:34:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/400f0c55e4040ec7a6d0ebd3226537283967368e', 'message': "Add support for DB2 datastore in Trove

The following features have been implemented in this patchset:
- Launch
- Reboot
- Terminate
- Resize Volume
- Create/Delete/List database(s)
- Create/Delete/List user(s)
- List Access
- Included unit tests for the different methods

I would recommend using flavor.medium atleast when creating a
DB2 server instance. DB2 Express-C requires atleast 2GB of RAM.

Another point to note is how DB2 creates and deletes users.
There isnt a notion of a DB2 user in DB2 unlike in the case of
MySQL. When we create a user for DB2, the process involves first
creating an OS user and then granting privileges to this user for
the given database(s).

Currently all the DB2 queries are run from command line. One of
the enhancements that can be made is to use the DB2 SQLAlchemy
driver to run these queries. This requires the guest agent to know
about the username, password and database name to connect to. We
can use the 'db2inst1' user(which is the instance user for the DB2
server instance created) but since DB2 doesnt track the passwords,
there isnt an easy way to get the password unless we stored it in a
file or use a similar mechanism. Since I am not sure how safe that
is, I decided to go with running the commands from command line.

TODO:
- add more documentation for each method to include details of
  how DB2 creates users and databases.

Change-Id: If95686dd37d2730a4d00f4010fa8515f33a8e337
Implements: blueprint db2-plugin-for-trove
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-03-17 03:45:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/048229509b9568f3bb7959e52fa1e98c058782d2', 'message': "Add support for DB2 datastore in Trove

"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-03-17 16:51:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/5af8a8f7bae19cebce17d0fd76692c8482790eed', 'message': "Add support for DB2 datastore in Trove

This feature will provide support for a new SQL datastore in
Trove. Users will be able to provision a DB2 server instance
and perform various functions as listed below. The risk of
regression is very minimal since there is no code changes to
the base Trove code. The guest agent for DB2 uses the existing
API's supported by Trove to provide the functionalities
mentioned below.

The following features have been implemented in this patchset:
- Launch
- Reboot
- Terminate
- Resize Volume
- Create/Delete/List database(s)
- Create/Delete/List user(s)
- List Access
- Included unit tests for the different methods

I would recommend using flavor.medium atleast when creating a
DB2 server instance. DB2 Express-C requires atleast 2GB of RAM.

Another point to note is how DB2 creates and deletes users.
There isnt a notion of a DB2 user in DB2 unlike in the case of
MySQL. When we create a user for DB2, the process involves first
creating an OS user and then granting privileges to this user for
the given database(s).

Currently all the DB2 queries are run from command line. One of
the enhancements that can be made is to use the DB2 SQLAlchemy
driver to run these queries. This requires the guest agent to know
about the username, password and database name to connect to. We
can use the 'db2inst1' user(which is the instance user for the DB2
server instance created) but since DB2 doesnt track the passwords,
there isnt an easy way to get the password unless we stored it in a
file or use a similar mechanism. Since I am not sure how safe that
is, I decided to go with running the commands from command line.

Change-Id: If95686dd37d2730a4d00f4010fa8515f33a8e337
Implements: blueprint db2-plugin-for-trove

There isnt a notion of a DB2 user in DB2 unlike in the case of
MySQL. When we create a user for DB2, the process involves first
creating an OS user and then granting privileges to this user for
the given database(s).

Currently all the DB2 queries are run from command line. One of
the enhancements that can be made is to use the DB2 SQLAlchemy
driver to run these queries. This requires the guest agent to know
about the username, password and database name to connect to. We
can use the 'db2inst1' user(which is the instance user for the DB2
server instance created) but since DB2 doesnt track the passwords,
there isnt an easy way to get the password unless we stored it in a
file or use a similar mechanism. Since I am not sure how safe that
is, I decided to go with running the commands from command line.

Change-Id: If95686dd37d2730a4d00f4010fa8515f33a8e337
Implements: blueprint db2-plugin-for-trove

commit_message:
Add support for DB2 datastore in Trove

This feature will provide support for a new SQL datastore in
Trove. Users will be able to provision a DB2 server instance
and perform various functions as listed below. The risk of
regression is very minimal since there is no code changes to
the base Trove code. The guest agent for DB2 uses the existing
API's supported by Trove to provide the functionalities
mentioned below.

The following features have been implemented in this patchset:
- Launch
- Reboot
- Terminate
- Resize Volume/Instance
- Create/Delete/List database(s)
- Create/Delete/List user(s)
- List Access
- Included unit tests for the different methods

DB2 Express-C can be installed on a server that satisfy the
memory requirements of 512MB to 4GB of RAM.

Another point to note is how DB2 creates and deletes users.
There isn't a notion of a DB2 user in DB2 unlike in the case of
MySQL. When we create a user for DB2, the process involves first
creating an OS user and then granting privileges to this user for
the given database(s).

Currently all the DB2 queries are run from command line. One of
the enhancements that can be made is to use the DB2 SQLAlchemy
driver to run these queries. This requires the guest agent to know
about the username and password to connect to. We can use the
'db2inst1' user (which is the instance user for the DB2 server
instance created) but since DB2 does not track the passwords, there
isn't an easy way to get the password unless we stored it in a
file or use a similar mechanism. Since I am not sure how safe that
is, I decided to go with running the commands from command line.

Change-Id: If95686dd37d2730a4d00f4010fa8515f33a8e337
Implements: blueprint db2-plugin-for-trove
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/93/164293/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Don't eagerly load ranges from IPAllocationPool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-27 03:24:59.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/models_v2.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/abc12279f774bafdc83e03234ef2bad679072a8b', 'message': "Don't eagerly load ranges from IPAllocationPool

The subnet object eagerly loads the IPAllocationPools
associated with it. Each of these was eagerly loading
the IPAvailabilityRange objects associated with it.
On a large subnet with lots of churn, this could be
thousands of records. All of these records were being
loaded for every call to get_subnet, which means all
get_subnets, get_networks, and so-on. icky

This patch changes the relationship between IPAllocationPool
and available_ranges to a 'select' load, so they won't be
loaded until referenced. On my test system with a subnet
that contained 10k ports, this changed the subnet-show time
from 4.7 seconds to 0.56 seconds.

There is no performance downside to this in the upstream
code. At the time of this patch, there were no references
to 'available_ranges' on an IPAllocationPool result. The
logic that deals with the available ranges queries them
explicitly using join statements.

Change-Id: Ia94ce9437ad21e4f21526ba84213fd673693db34
Closes-Bug: #1437131
"}]
commit_message:
Don't eagerly load ranges from IPAllocationPool

The subnet object eagerly loads the IPAllocationPools
associated with it. Each of these was eagerly loading
the IPAvailabilityRange objects associated with it.
On a large subnet with lots of churn, this could be
thousands of records. All of these records were being
loaded for every call to get_subnet, which means all
get_subnets, get_networks, and so-on. icky

This patch changes the relationship between IPAllocationPool
and available_ranges to a 'select' load, so they won't be
loaded until referenced. On my test system with a subnet
that contained 10k ports, this changed the subnet-show time
from 4.7 seconds to 0.56 seconds.

There is no performance downside to this in the upstream
code. At the time of this patch, there were no references
to 'available_ranges' on an IPAllocationPool result. The
logic that deals with the available ranges queries them
explicitly using join statements.

Change-Id: Ia94ce9437ad21e4f21526ba84213fd673693db34
Closes-Bug: #1437131
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/14/168214/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: lazy="select",

commit_message:
Add API to create ecp wrapped saml assertion

Create a new API that gives users the option to wrap a token based
SAML assertion in an ECP envelope.

Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte Sousa <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Change-Id: Ieffeb6cf34b225f0704321fa64fe6dfc227add8e
Closes-Bug: 1426128
bp: ecp-wrapped-saml-assertions

commit_message:
Add relay_state_prefix to Service Provider

To correctly create an ECP assertion, a keystone acting as an
identity provider needs to know the relay state's prefix used
by the service provider. This is usually 'ss:mem', but is
configurable with mod_shib.

Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte Sousa <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Change-Id: I55fe059df8b73e8c6d1f195a958e73ee0a321015
Partial-Bug: 1426128
bp: ecp-wrapped-saml-assertions

commit_message:
WaitCondition timeout attribute should be a number

According to Heat documentation, AWS::CloudFormation::WaitCondition
timeout attribute should be a number but magnum templates use strings:

  master_wait_condition:
    type: "AWS::CloudFormation::WaitCondition"
    properties:
      Handle:
        get_resource: master_wait_handle
      Timeout: "6000"

This change replaces string timeouts ("6000") by number timeout (6000).

Change-Id: I2ad6825899dca551a152c101832c2d38c61a113e
Closes-Bug: #1437234

commit_message:
Enable nova create/delete to wait for completion

This patch adds support to nova server operations so that create and
delete can be done synchronously.

Change-Id: I31482d8166a32886f89c8e52480e8243d743cf38
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/60/168560/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time from oslo_config import cfg from senlin.common import exception timeout = cfg.CONF.default_action_timeout if 'timeout' in params: timeout = params.pop('timeout') server_obj = None try: server_obj = obj.create(self.session) try: server_obj.wait_for_status(self.session, wait=timeout) except sdk.exc.ResourceFailure as ex: raise exception.ProfileOperationFailed(ex.message) except sdk.exc.ResourceTimeout as ex: raise exception.ProfileOperationTimeout(ex.message) return server_obj timeout = cfg.CONF.default_action_timeout if 'timeout' in params: timeout = params.pop('timeout') total_sleep = 0 while total_sleep < timeout: try: obj.get(self.session) except sdk.exc.HttpException as ex: parsed = sdk.exc.parse_exception(ex) if isinstance(parsed, sdk.exc.HTTPNotFound): return raise ex time.sleep(5) total_sleep += 5 raise exception.ProfileOperationTimeout(ex.message)

These 2 exceptions are about profile operation failure and timeouts.

Change-Id: Ie0dcf2c1af097596f2794eee36691b2ec40ae1c6
'}]
commit_message:
Add 2 new exception types for profile operations

These 2 exceptions are about profile operation failure and timeouts.

subject: Revert "objects: introduce numa topology limits objects"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-23 10:10:30.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_rpcapi.py', 'nova/objects/numa.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/test_hardware.py', 'nova/tests/unit/compute/test_resource_tracker.py', 'nova/scheduler/filters/numa_topology_filter.py', 'nova/tests/unit/objects/test_numa.py', 'nova/compute/claims.py', 'nova/tests/unit/pci/test_stats.py', 'nova/tests/unit/compute/test_claims.py', 'nova/tests/unit/objects/test_objects.py', 'nova/virt/hardware.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py', 'nova/compute/rpcapi.py', 'nova/tests/unit/scheduler/filters/test_numa_topology_filters.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7b6b8a7c99ece23288e0c17297d6c1fc6a01244b', 'message': 'Revert "objects: introduce numa topology limits objects"

This reverts commit 0b0f1515acd43ec3b39f2f748161890c80a8a939.

The patch under revert objectifies the NUMA topology limits being sent
as part of the build_and_run_instance RPC call (good) but also refactors
the code to send cpu and memory ratio for all cells as part of the
limits dict argument to the RPC call (very bad).

There are several reasons why this is bad: Firstly - semantics. We are packing
things that are clearly not limits in a non-versioned and undocumented
dict argument named "limits". This alone is bad enough and is a prime example of
"breaking windows" and leaving them broken. As far as I could tell - the
only added benefit of this is marginal savings in the message payload size,
at the cost of making a complete mess.

Secondly - this introduces
strong coupling between NUMA implementation in Nova, and the way scheduler
implements oversubscription. Ratios are clearly an internal
implementation detail of the scheduler (at this moment), and limits
are obviously a more general concepts we should be exposing in the external
facing contract. We already established that mixing the two is bad,
even without the added leakage.

This is surely a regression on the way to making Gantt a reality.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/unit/objects/test_objects.py

Change-Id: Ic622d59059cb0a5b5185c167f191ce466ec9f994
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "objects: introduce numa topology limits objects"

This reverts commit 0b0f1515acd43ec3b39f2f748161890c80a8a939.

The patch under revert objectifies the NUMA topology limits being sent
as part of the build_and_run_instance RPC call (good) but also refactors
the code to send cpu and memory ratio for all cells as part of the
limits dict argument to the RPC call (very bad).

There are several reasons why this is bad: Firstly - semantics. We are packing
things that are clearly not limits in a non-versioned and undocumented
dict argument named "limits". This alone is bad enough and is a prime example of
"breaking windows" and leaving them broken. As far as I could tell - the
only added benefit of this is marginal savings in the message payload size,
at the cost of making a complete mess.

Secondly - this introduces
strong coupling between NUMA implementation in Nova, and the way scheduler
implements oversubscription. Ratios are clearly an internal
implementation detail of the scheduler (at this moment), and limits
are obviously a more general concepts we should be exposing in the external
facing contract. We already established that mixing the two is bad,
even without the added leakage.

This is surely a regression on the way to making Gantt a reality.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/unit/objects/test_objects.py

Change-Id: Ic622d59059cb0a5b5185c167f191ce466ec9f994
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/67/166767/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.virt import hardware limits_topology = hardware.VirtNUMALimitTopology.from_json( host.limits['numa_topology']) self.assertEqual(limits_topology.cells[0].cpu_limit, 42) self.assertEqual(limits_topology.cells[1].cpu_limit, 42) self.assertEqual(limits_topology.cells[0].memory_limit, 665) self.assertEqual(limits_topology.cells[1].memory_limit, 665)

'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766', {'port': new_props_update} ).AndReturn(None) fake_groups_list = { 'security_groups': [ { 'tenant_id': 'dc4b074874244f7693dd65583733a758', 'id': '0389f747-7785-4757-b7bb-2ab07e4b09c3', 'name': 'default', 'security_group_rules': [], 'description': 'no protocol' } ] } self.m.StubOutWithMock(neutronclient.Client, 'list_security_groups') neutronclient.Client.list_security_groups().AndReturn( fake_groups_list) neutronclient.Client.update_port( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766', {'port': new_props_update1} ).AndReturn(None) update again to test port without security group update_snippet = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition(port.name, port.type(), new_props1) self.assertIsNone(port.handle_update(update_snippet, {}, {})) self.m.VerifyAll() def test_port_needs_update(self): props = {'network_id': u'net1234', 'name': utils.PhysName('test_stack', 'port'), 'admin_state_up': True, 'device_owner': u'network:dhcp'} neutronV20.find_resourceid_by_name_or_id( mox.IsA(neutronclient.Client), 'network', 'net1234' ).MultipleTimes().AndReturn('net1234') neutronclient.Client.create_port( {'port': props} ).AndReturn({'port': { "status": "BUILD", "id": "fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766" }}) neutronclient.Client.show_port( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766' ).AndReturn({'port': { "status": "ACTIVE", "id": "fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766", "fixed_ips": { "subnet_id": "d0e971a6-a6b4-4f4c-8c88-b75e9c120b7e", "ip_address": "10.0.0.2" } }}) self.m.ReplayAll() # create port t = props.copy() # test always replace new_props['replacement_policy'] = 'REPLACE_ALWAYS' update_snippet = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition(port.name, port.type(), new_props) new_props['replacement_policy'] = 'AUTO' update_snippet = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition(port.name, port.type(), new_props) self.assertTrue(port._needs_update(update_snippet, port.frozen_definition(), new_props, props, None)) self.m.VerifyAll() def test_get_port_attributes(self): subnet_dict = {'name': 'test-subnet', 'enable_dhcp': True, 'network_id': 'net1234', 'dns_nameservers': [], 'tenant_id': utils.PhysName('test_stack', 'port'), 'admin_state_up': True, 'device_owner': 'network:dhcp', 'binding:vnic_type': 'direct' } new_port_prop = port_prop.copy() new_port_prop['binding:vnic_type'] = new_port_prop['replacement_policy'] = 'AUTO' new_port_prop['network'] = u'net1234' neutronV20.find_resourceid_by_name_or_id( mox.IsA(neutronclient.Client), 'network', 'net1234' ).AndReturn('net1234') neutronV20.find_resourceid_by_name_or_id( mox.IsA(neutronclient.Client), 'subnet', 'sub1234' ).AndReturn('sub1234') neutronclient.Client.create_port({'port': port_prop}).AndReturn( {'port': { }}) prop_update2 = prop_update.copy() prop_update2['binding:vnic_type'] = 'direct' neutronclient.Client.update_port( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766', {'port': prop_update2} ).AndReturn(None) neutronclient.Client.show_port( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766' ).AndReturn({'port': { "status": "ACTIVE", "id": "fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766" }}) self.m.ReplayAll() t = template_format.parse(neutron_port_template) t['Resources']['port']['Properties']['binding:vnic_type'] = 'direct' stack = utils.parse_stack(t) port = stack['port'] scheduler.TaskRunner(port.create)() self.assertEqual('direct', port.properties['binding:vnic_type']) # update to normal update_snippet = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition(port.name, port.type(), new_port_prop) scheduler.TaskRunner(port.update, update_snippet)() self.assertEqual((port.UPDATE, port.COMPLETE), port.state) self.assertEqual('normal', port.properties['binding:vnic_type']) # update back to direct new_port_prop['binding:vnic_type'] = 'direct' update_snippet = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition(port.name, port.type(), new_port_prop) scheduler.TaskRunner(port.update, update_snippet)() self.assertEqual((port.UPDATE, port.COMPLETE), port.state) self.assertEqual('direct', port.properties['binding:vnic_type']) self.m.VerifyAll()

commit_message:
Add a relay_state_prefix to the service provider resource

Add a 'relay_state_prefix' to SPs. This value is used for
generating an ECP based assertion, it must also be configurable
since it's configurable on each service provider (via mod_shib).

Change-Id: If2ed5004c092b9553765a354deb9a5fb53d95aa8
bp: ecp-wrapped-saml-assertions

commit_message:
Revert "Move InstanceClaimTestCase.test_claim_and_audit"

This commit is needed to be able to do a clean revert in the follow up
patch which holds more info on the reasoning. This patch itself is not
problematic on it's own.

This reverts commit deb7a2402fc29294391616168ae7a074ef9ccfb9.

Change-Id: Ibdc9336374b591f09fe5a5b322541347b5f052b6

subject: libvirt: Remove minidom usage in driver.py
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-14 08:00:29.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/8aa429897c640434d974d90ea002d7fe8217519d', 'message': "libvirt: Remove minidom usage in driver.py

We usually use etree to parse/handle xml in driver, and etree
supports XPath to find specific node, so we don't need find
the node with comparing its tag and attribute. This commit
removed the minidom usage and uses Xpath in method get_vnc_console
and get_spice_console.

Note: Unit tests had covered this change in

Change-Id: Idd15d2b6c5436cf80520b76ee4025acfe536ec8e
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Remove minidom usage in driver.py

We usually use etree to parse/handle xml in driver, and etree
supports XPath to find specific node, so we don't need find
the node with comparing its tag and attribute. This commit
removed the minidom usage and uses Xpath in method get_vnc_console
and get_spice_console.

Note: Unit tests had covered this change in
unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py

Partial-Bug: #1407915
Change-Id: Idd15d2b6c5436cf80520b76ee4025acfe536ec8e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/164415/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: xml_dom = etree.fromstring(xml) graphic = xml_dom.find("./devices/graphics[@type='vnc']") if graphic is not None: return graphic.get('port') xml_dom = etree.fromstring(xml) graphic = xml_dom.find("./devices/graphics[@type='spice']") if graphic is not None: return (graphic.get('port'), graphic.get('tlsPort'))
deleted_lines: from xml.dom import minidom dom = minidom.parseString(xml) for graphic in dom.getElementsByTagName('graphics'): if graphic.getAttribute('type') == 'vnc': return graphic.getAttribute('port') # TODO(sleepsonthefloor): use etree instead of minidom dom = minidom.parseString(xml) for graphic in dom.getElementsByTagName('graphics'): if graphic.getAttribute('type') == 'spice': return (graphic.getAttribute('port'), graphic.getAttribute('tlsPort'))

commit_message:
Merge V2 and V2.1 functional tests

Currently v2 and v2.1 have separate functional tests and their
corresponding sample files. As v2 and v2.1 are supposed to be identical,
there is overhead to maintain two set of functional tests and sample files.

We can have one set of tests which can run for both v2 and v2.1.

This commit use the testscenearios to generate the tests one for v2 and one for v2.1
and make v2.1 tests to run against v2.1 plugins by redirecting /v2 endpoint to v2.1
plugins in api-paste.ini

As example this commit merge flavor APIs functional tests between v2 & v2.1.
In V2 flavor API has following extensions
- Flavor_swap
- Flavor_disabled
- Flavorextradata
In V2.1 above extensions have been merged together in flavor plugins

NOTE- As testscenarios is applied in base class. v2 tests will be generated
for all the existing tests but for tests which are not merged yet
their v2 generated tests will be skipped till they gets
merged. After merge, both version tests are expected to pass like
flavor tests in this patch. So you may see lot of skipped tests
which is expected and will gets disappear as tests gets merged.

Change-Id: I0e0262f818c7d7fb15528b16d3225b9578910996

subject: Extract EC PUT to ECObjController
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-17 05:58:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/143f12bb4fde94ab8b05ade5f7f86decfa5f4674', 'message': "Validate the PUT method extraction for EC

I'd like to experiment further with what an EC PUT path merge could
look like against master if we tried to muddle with the replicated
object PUT path *as little as possible*.

Unfortunately because the replicated PUT path is currently a
terrific big ball of mud there's basically no hope short of
duplicating the entire gigantic unless we first do a little method
extraction surgery on master's PUT.  Given that should be a priority
anyway we could theoretically suggest that change up for review
against master as soon as we nail down the interface.

I discovered *some* overlap in EC and Replicated policies in
_get_put_connections, but found most of the rest of the PUT path
under _store_object had some important differences - so I tried to
put the methods on the ReplicatedObjectController back to how they
would look on master after the PUT method extraction change.

I think there may well still be some cleanup to be had for
replicated PUT by adopting the Putter class pattern - but I don't
think it's worth it if we also have to plumb all of the policy
specific behavior qualifiers (if requires_multiphase_put, etc) into
a common Putter class and feel somewhat less enthusiastic about the
class in general if we'd just have to subclass it per policy.  So
maybe the ECPutter eventually gets absorbed back into the EC methods
that are being over-ridden.  In the meantime a side effect making
Putter EC-specific was that many conditionals and parameters were
able to be removed - reducing the cyclomatic complexity of it's
methods and making it more obvious how request handling flows in the
case of EC PUT without having to keep track of state in your head or
learn a bunch of policy specific jargon.

There's some maintenance risk in the larger extracted methods (e.g.
_transfer_data and _get_put_responses) where the common code and
policy specific behaviors intermix more closely - we should try to
better identify more of the common patterns and to break those
methods up further to avoid duplicating common error handling.  This
work should continue on feature/ec.  That can also happen
organically as that code mutates - instead of fixing it in two
places you always have the option to extract it and fix it in one
place.

However, IMHO, if the duplicated code in the EC PUT path is the
price we pay in the sort term to get to an EC beta review that more
obviously preserves the existing behaviors and characteristics of
the replicated PUT path while at the same time making *that* code
easier to maintain - I think it's probably worth further
investigation.  Please comment.

Change-Id: I17b2d4fcd60ad0a574be37031ec0ce51a3514326

commit_message:
Extract EC PUT to ECObjController

Add some tests, fix some bugs, clean up the diff the master.

You should look at the Router thing - trying to adopt a pattern we
used on the object-server.

Change-Id: I17b2d4fcd60ad0a574be37031ec0ce51a3514326
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/50/164950/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
normalize_delete_at_timestamp, public, get_expirer_container, replication_quorum_size)class ECPutter(object): This is here mostly to wrap up the fact that all EC PUTs are chunked because of the mime boundry footer trick and the first half of the two-phase PUT conversation handling. def __init__(self, conn, node, resp, path, connect_duration, mime_boundary): self.chunk_hasher = md5() def end_of_object_data(self, footer_metadata): footer_body = json.dumps(footer_metadata) footer_md5 = md5(footer_body).hexdigest() tail_boundary = ("--%s" % (self.mime_boundary,)) message_parts = [ ("
--%s
" % self.mime_boundary), "X-Document: object metadata
", "Content-MD5: %s
" % footer_md5, "
", footer_body, "
", tail_boundary, ] self.queue.put("".join(message_parts)) to_send = "%x
%s
" % (len(chunk), chunk) chunked=False): mime_boundary = "%.64x" % random.randint(0, 16 ** 64) headers = HeaderKeyDict(headers) # We're going to be adding some unknown amount of data to the # request, so we can't use an explicit content length, and thus # we must use chunked encoding. headers['Transfer-Encoding'] = 'chunked' headers['Expect'] = '100-continue' if 'Content-Length' in headers: headers['X-Backend-Obj-Content-Length'] = \ headers.pop('Content-Length') headers['X-Backend-Obj-Multipart-Mime-Boundary'] = mime_boundary headers['X-Backend-Obj-Metadata-Footer'] = 'yes' headers['X-Backend-Obj-Multiphase-Commit'] = 'yes' if not can_send_metadata_footer: if not can_handle_multiphase_put: return cls(conn, node, resp, path, connect_duration, mime_boundary) def _connect_put_node(self, nodes, part, path, headers, logger_thread_locals): Make a connection for a repliated object. This method pre-dates the PUT method extraction change. for node in nodes: try: start_time = time.time() with ConnectionTimeout(self.app.conn_timeout): conn = http_connect( node['ip'], node['port'], node['device'], part, 'PUT', path, headers) self.app.set_node_timing(node, time.time() - start_time) with Timeout(self.app.node_timeout): resp = conn.getexpect() if resp.status == HTTP_CONTINUE: conn.resp = None conn.node = node return conn elif is_success(resp.status) or resp.status == HTTP_CONFLICT: conn.resp = resp conn.node = node return conn elif headers['If-None-Match'] is not None and \ resp.status == HTTP_PRECONDITION_FAILED: conn.resp = resp conn.node = node return conn elif resp.status == HTTP_INSUFFICIENT_STORAGE: self.app.error_limit(node, _('ERROR Insufficient Storage')) elif is_server_error(resp.status): self.app.error_occurred( node, _('ERROR %(status)d Expect: 100-continue ' 'From Object Server') % { 'status': resp.status}) def _get_put_responses(self, req, conns, nodes, **kwargs): Collect replicated object responses. def get_conn_response(conn): try: with Timeout(self.app.node_timeout): if conn.resp: return (conn, conn.resp) else: return (conn, conn.getresponse()) conn.node, _('Object'), _('Trying to get final status of PUT to %s') % req.path) pile = GreenAsyncPile(len(conns)) for conn in conns: pile.spawn(get_conn_response, conn) def _handle_response(conn, response): bodies.append(response.read()) if response.status == HTTP_INSUFFICIENT_STORAGE: self.app.error_limit(conn.node, conn.node, for (conn, response) in pile: if response: _handle_response(conn, response) if self.have_quorum(statuses, len(nodes)): break for (conn, response) in finished_quickly: if response: _handle_response(conn, response) while len(statuses) < len(nodes): statuses.append(HTTP_SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE) reasons.append('') bodies.append('') return statuses, reasons, bodies, etags # if the above try block blows up that will be raised up to # caller of _make_copy_request with the attributes reparied, we # only get to this return if the GET request is completed. def _get_put_connections(self, req, nodes, min_conns, partition, outgoing_headers, policy, expect=True): """ Get connections to nodes for PUT, used by both replicated and erasure coded objects. This method was added in the PUT method extraction change """ obj_ring = policy.object_ring if expect: pile.spawn(self._connect_put_node, node_iter, partition, req.swift_entity_path, nheaders, self.app.logger.thread_locals) conns = [conn for conn in pile if conn] statuses = [conn.resp.status for conn in conns if conn.resp] if req.if_none_match is not None and '*' in req.if_none_match: if HTTP_PRECONDITION_FAILED in statuses: # If we find any copy of the file, it shouldn't be uploaded self.app.logger.debug( _('Object PUT returning 412, %(statuses)r'), {'statuses': statuses}) raise HTTPPreconditionFailed(request=req) timestamps = [HeaderKeyDict(conn.resp.getheaders()).get( 'X-Backend-Timestamp') for conn in conns if conn.resp] self._check_min_conn(req, conns, min_conns) return conns def _check_min_conn(self, req, conns, min_conns, msg=None): msg = msg or 'Object PUT returning 503, %(conns)s/%(nodes)s ' \ 'required connections' if len(conns) < min_conns: self.app.logger.error((msg), {'conns': len(conns), 'nodes': min_conns}) raise HTTPServiceUnavailable(request=req) def _transfer_data(self, req, policy, data_source, conns, nodes, min_conns): """ Transfer data for a replicated object. This method was added in the PUT method extraction change """ try: with ContextPool(len(nodes)) as pool: for conn in conns: conn.failed = False conn.queue = Queue(self.app.put_queue_depth) pool.spawn(self._send_file, conn, req.path) if req.is_chunked: for conn in conns: conn.queue.put('0

') for conn in list(conns): if not conn.failed: conn.queue.put( '%x
%s
' % (len(chunk), chunk) if req.is_chunked else chunk) else: conn.close() conns.remove(conn) self._check_min_conn( req, conns, min_conns, msg='Object PUT exceptions during' ' send, %(conns)s/%(nodes)s required connections') for conn in conns: if conn.queue.unfinished_tasks: conn.queue.join() conns = [conn for conn in conns if not conn.failed] self._check_min_conn( req, conns, min_conns, msg='Object PUT exceptions after last send, ' '%(conns)s/%(nodes)s required connections') self, req, data_source, policy, container_nodes, container_partition, delete_at_nodes, delete_at_container, delete_at_part): """ Store an replicated object. This method was added in the PUT method extraction change """ if not all((nodes, container_nodes)): return HTTPNotFound() req, len(nodes), container_partition, container_nodes, # RFC2616:8.2.3 disallows 100-continue without a body if (req.content_length > 0) or req.is_chunked: expect = True else: expect = False min_conns = replication_quorum_size(len(nodes)) conns = self._get_put_connections( req, nodes, min_conns, partition, outgoing_headers, policy, expect=expect) try: self._transfer_data(req, policy, data_source, conns, nodes, min_conns) statuses, reasons, bodies, etags = self._get_put_responses( req, conns, nodes) finally: for conn in conns: conn.close() if len(etags) > 1: _('Object PUT'), etag=etag) req, data_source, policy, def _connect_put_node(self, node_iter, part, path, headers, logger_thread_locals): """ Make a connection for a erasure encoded object. Connects to the first working node that it finds in node_iter and sends over the request headers. Returns a Putter to handle the rest of the streaming, or None if no working nodes were found. """ # the object server will get different bytes, so these # values do not apply (Content-Length might, in general, but # in the specific case of replication vs. EC, it doesn't). headers.pop('Content-Length', None) headers.pop('Etag', None) self.app.logger.thread_locals = logger_thread_locals for node in node_iter: try: putter = ECPutter.connect( node, part, path, headers, conn_timeout=self.app.conn_timeout, node_timeout=self.app.node_timeout) self.app.set_node_timing(node, putter.connect_duration) return putter except InsufficientStorage: self.app.error_limit(node, _('ERROR Insufficient Storage')) except PutterConnectError as e: self.app.error_occurred( node, _('ERROR %(status)d Expect: 100-continue ' 'From Object Server') % { 'status': e.status}) except (Exception, Timeout): self.app.exception_occurred( node, _('Object'), _('Expect: 100-continue on %s') % path) def _transfer_data(self, req, policy, data_source, putters, nodes, min_conns, etag_hasher): """ Transfer data for an erasure coded object. This method was added in the PUT method extraction change """ bytes_transferred = 0 chunk_transform = policy.chunk_transformer(len(nodes)) chunk_transform.send(None) def send_chunk(chunk): if etag_hasher: etag_hasher.update(chunk) backend_chunks = chunk_transform.send(chunk) if backend_chunks is None: # condition to be met before starting 2nd PUT phase final_phase = False statuses, reasons, bodies, _junk, quorum = \ self._get_put_responses( req, putters, len(nodes), final_phase, min_conns, need_quorum=need_quorum) if quorum: # Return statuses, quorum result if indicated by 'need_quorum' and etags if this is a final phase or a multiphase PUT transaction. :param req: the request :param putters: list of putters for the request :param num_nodes: number of nodes involved :param final_phase: boolean indicating if this is the last phase :param min_responses: minimum needed when not requiring quorum :param need_quorum: boolean indicating if quorum is required """ statuses = [] reasons = [] bodies = [] etags = set() def get_put_response(putter): try: resp = putter.await_response( self.app.node_timeout, not final_phase) return (putter, resp) except (Exception, Timeout): self.app.exception_occurred( putter.node, _('Object'), _('Trying to get status of PUT to %s') % req.path) return (None, None) pile = GreenAsyncPile(len(putters)) for putter in putters: pile.spawn(get_put_response, putter) def _handle_response(putter, response): statuses.append(response.status) reasons.append(response.reason) if final_phase: bodies.append(response.read()) if response.status == HTTP_INSUFFICIENT_STORAGE: self.app.error_limit(putter.node, _('ERROR Insufficient Storage')) elif response.status >= HTTP_INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR: self.app.error_occurred( putter.node, _('ERROR %(status)d %(body)s From Object Server ' 're: %(path)s') % {'status': response.status, 'body': bodies[-1][:1024], 'path': req.path}) elif is_success(response.status): etags.add(response.getheader('etag').strip('"')) quorum = False for (putter, response) in pile: if response: _handle_response(putter, response) if need_quorum and final_phase: # check quorum only when this is the final phase of a # multiphase PUT. commit_message:
Fix replacement of exception category list

Make config of ADD_EXCEPTIONS plugin append to the
exception category list and not replace it.

Change-Id: Ib52012bc93311ac019312b0f92b5fcb8842de53d
Co-Authored-By: Eric Peterson <eric.peterson1@twcable.com>
Closes-Bug: #1404032
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/32/143832/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: exceptions = horizon_config.get('exceptions', {}) for category, exc_list in config.get('ADD_EXCEPTIONS', {}).iteritems(): exceptions[category] = exceptions.get(category, ()) + exc_list

commit_message:
Add novncproxy_base_url to nova::vncproxy

The solution to the bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1409142
introduced some security changes to nova that require the nova::vncproxy
to assure that the novncproxy_base_url is present on the nova configuration
file.

Resolves: rhbz#1204482

Change-Id: Icd3bab6371d4787e160c79ffe02e8a5744202462
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/95/168195/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it { is_expected.to contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/novncproxy_base_url').with(:value => 'http://0.0.0.0:6080/vnc_auto.html') }

commit_message:
Change the way values are migrated for 007_add_remote_id_table

Rather than relying on the model (which may change), we should
create the value based on the old table, and add each new entry to
the new table.

Implements: blueprint idp-id-registration

Change-Id: I0317ef934adf7119915b998dee8b9035faea514a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/39/168239/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker remote_idp_entry = {'idp_id': identity.id, 'remote_id': identity.remote_id} new_session = sessionmaker(bind=migrate_engine)() remote_id_table.insert(remote_idp_entry).execute() new_session.commit()

Move common neutron module tests to separate file

- Refacore couple tests in neutron/test_neutron.py
- Move all other tests to neutron/test_neutron_resources.py file.

neutronclient.Client.list_dhcp_agent_hosting_networks( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766' ).AndReturn({ "agents": [{ "admin_state_up": True, "agent_type": "DHCP agent", "alive": True, "binary": "neutron-dhcp-agent", "configurations": { "dhcp_driver": "DummyDriver", "dhcp_lease_duration": 86400, "networks": 0, "ports": 0, "subnets": 0, "use_namespaces": True}, "created_at": "2014-03-20 05:12:34", "description": None, "heartbeat_timestamp": "2014-03-20 05:12:34", "host": "hostname", "id": "28c25a04-3f73-45a7-a2b4-59e183943ddc", "started_at": "2014-03-20 05:12:34", "topic": "dhcp_agent" }] }) neutronclient.Client.add_network_to_dhcp_agent( 'bb09cfcd-5277-473d-8336-d4ed8628ae68', {'network_id': u'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766'} ).AndReturn(None) neutronclient.Client.remove_network_from_dhcp_agent( '28c25a04-3f73-45a7-a2b4-59e183943ddc', 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766' ).AndReturn(None) neutronclient.Client.update_network( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766', {'network': { 'shared': True, 'name': 'mynet', 'admin_state_up': True }}).AndReturn(None) # Delete script neutronclient.Client.delete_network( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766' ).AndReturn(None) neutronclient.Client.show_network( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766' ).AndRaise(qe.NetworkNotFoundClient(status_code=404)) neutronclient.Client.delete_network( 'fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766' ).AndRaise(qe.NetworkNotFoundClient(status_code=404)) self.m.ReplayAll() t = template_format.parse(neutron_template) stack = utils.parse_stack(t) rsrc = self.create_net(t, stack, 'network') # assert the implicit dependency between the gateway and the interface deps = stack.dependencies[stack['router_interface']] self.assertIn(stack['gateway'], deps) # assert the implicit dependency between the gateway and the subnet deps = stack.dependencies[stack['subnet']] self.assertIn(stack['gateway'], deps) rsrc.validate() ref_id = rsrc.FnGetRefId() self.assertEqual('fc68ea2c-b60b-4b4f-bd82-94ec81110766', ref_id) self.assertIsNone(rsrc.FnGetAtt('status')) self.assertEqual('ACTIVE', rsrc.FnGetAtt('status')) self.assertRaises( exception.InvalidTemplateAttribute, rsrc.FnGetAtt, 'Foo') prop_diff = { "name": "mynet", "dhcp_agent_ids": [ "bb09cfcd-5277-473d-8336-d4ed8628ae68" ] } props = copy.copy(rsrc.properties.data) props.update(prop_diff) update_snippet = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition(rsrc.name, rsrc.type(), props) rsrc.handle_update(update_snippet, {}, prop_diff) scheduler.TaskRunner(rsrc.delete)() rsrc.state_set(rsrc.CREATE, rsrc.COMPLETE, 'to delete again') scheduler.TaskRunner(rsrc.delete)() self.m.VerifyAll() class resource_defns = stack.t.resource_definitions(stack) rsrc = provider_net.ProviderNet( 'provider_net', resource_defns['provider_network_vlan'], stack) return rsrc def test_create_provider_net(self): subject: Skip 'id' attribute to be explicitly deleted in TestCase
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-23 06:40:59.000000000', 'files': ['nova/test.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/905c2d2373a0c2f35f66f46d01e2a833550747fb', 'message': "Skip 'id' attribute to be explicitly deleted in TestCase

In very base test class (TestCase), addCleanup method (_clear_attrs())
is being added to explicitly delete the attributes of tests objects
to free up the memory. Details- I0e660b6c2a77c5613c5a523ba0a64c3d7f6dd128

v2 and v2.1 API has separate set of functional tests which is not good
as both API supposed to be same and can be tested by single set of tests.
Plan is to run one set of tests for both the v2 and v2.1 using testscenarios.

In that case, deleting attributes in existing way will cause issue.
If tests are being generated using testscenarios then, 'id' attribute is being
added during cloning the tests. And later that 'id' attribute is being used by
test suite to generate the results for each newly generated tests by testscenarios.
(Issue can be seen in I0e0262f818c7d7fb15528b16d3225b9578910996 PS10).

To make testscenarios work in functional tests, this commit skip the 'id' attribute
to be explicitly deleted in cleanup method.

Change-Id: I151d955545ec716f288c3ac465af7748851d79ed
"}]
commit_message:
Skip 'id' attribute to be explicitly deleted in TestCase

In very base test class (TestCase), addCleanup method (_clear_attrs())
is being added to explicitly delete the attributes of tests objects
to free up the memory. Details- I0e660b6c2a77c5613c5a523ba0a64c3d7f6dd128

v2 and v2.1 API has separate set of functional tests which is not good
as both API supposed to be same and can be tested by single set of tests.
Plan is to run one set of tests for both the v2 and v2.1 using testscenarios.

In that case, deleting attributes in existing way will cause issue.
If tests are being generated using testscenarios then, 'id' attribute is being
added during cloning the tests. And later that 'id' attribute is being used by
test suite to generate the results for each newly generated tests by testscenarios.
(Issue can be seen in I0e0262f818c7d7fb15528b16d3225b9578910996 PS10).

To make testscenarios work in functional tests, this commit skip the 'id' attribute
to be explicitly deleted in cleanup method.

Change-Id: I151d955545ec716f288c3ac465af7748851d79ed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/06/166706/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(gmann): Skip attribute 'id' because if tests are being # generated using testscenarios then, 'id' attribute is being # added during cloning the tests. And later that 'id' attribute # is being used by test suite to generate the results for each # newly generated tests by testscenarios. if key != 'id': del self.__dict__[key]

commit_message:
Move os-client-config to OpenStack section

os-client-config is now an OpenStack project, move it from StackForge to
OpenStack section in jenkins/jobs/projects.yaml.

Change-Id: Ia46198a379a4e0909912145229409a983fc9213b

commit_message:
[Launch Instance Fix] Add details to Select Flavor step

Add details to the Select Flavor step of the Angular-based launch
instance wizard. Details are charts indicating how much each flavor
affects the current user quota.

This commit also refactors the flavor step to not duplicate HTML
used for the allocated and available flavor tables. Instead a
directive provides a"flavor table" which is then reused for both
the allocated and available sections the parent transfer table.

Change-Id: I446051463d83aba9ecb0d862ca6c5b1e1b2181a9
Partial-Bug: 1433373
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/60/165260/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ( finalSpec.flavor ) { finalSpec.flavor_id = finalSpec.flavor.id; } else { finalSpec.flavor_id = null;

subject: VPNaaS Fix unit test breakage
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-27 20:18:46.000000000', 'files': ['neutron_vpnaas/tests/unit/services/vpn/device_drivers/test_ipsec.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/1864d99eb145c8fcf0eebb1f4b48a6c97260fb85', 'message': "VPNaaS Fix unit test breakage

Changing path to execute() so that it matches neutron changes.

Will do a separate commit to clean up the test module better so that
it doesn't rely on Neutron for this mock (I tried it earlier today,
but I found other issues and need more time for a robust fix).

Change-Id: Id9838233f75a43ae2fa68032251cd624abe38528
"}]
commit_message:
VPNaaS Fix unit test breakage

Changing path to execute() so that it matches neutron changes.

Will do a separate commit to clean up the test module better so that
it doesn't rely on Neutron for this mock (I tried it earlier today,
but I found other issues and need more time for a robust fix).

Change-Id: Id9838233f75a43ae2fa68032251cd624abe38528
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/72/168472/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'neutron.agent.common.utils.execute').start()

subject: Make ComputeAPIIpFilterTestCase a NoDBTestCase
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-20 21:15:16.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/dde0998997d655f1e308648c7041a22a17232113', 'message': 'Make ComputeAPIIpFilterTestCase a NoDBTestCase

There is no reason for these tests to use the
database so change the inheritance to NoDBTestCase.

Change-Id: I60f46882a41403b83650df56dc6660752cc51e6a
'}]
commit_message:
Make ComputeAPIIpFilterTestCase a NoDBTestCase

There is no reason for these tests to use the
database so change the inheritance to NoDBTestCase.

Change-Id: I60f46882a41403b83650df56dc6660752cc51e6a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/85/166385/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ComputeAPIIpFilterTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase): def setUp(self): super(ComputeAPIIpFilterTestCase, self).setUp() self.compute_api = compute.API()

Zero downtime config reload (log handling)

Pick up changes to log configuration on reload.

commit_message:
Cap maximum number of nodes in a cluster

* Max limit configurable in cue.conf
* Cue API post request (create cluster) will validate size is
  within this limit
* Added API test for cluster creation higher than limit is rejected.

closes-bug: 1427894

Change-Id: I7e979b22c519df83a44699bac3d45d2a3802f2f7

commit_message:
[Launch Instance fix] Fix decimal point

When the decimal point is too long, the instance percentage will be not
shown right in the instance detail form. Restrict decimal point to 2.

Change-Id: I126853251b0f9bff62c8edbb48df9146436b0b49
Closes-bug: #1434407

commit_message:
Fixes inconsistent Edit between tables & details

This patch addresses several instances where clicking Edit on a Detail
page (such as Edit Port on the Port Detail Page) gave either more or
less options than the equivalent action in the Table. This patch fixes
any occurences so that Edit ___ show the same form and fields regardless
of where it is clicked

Closes-bug: 1408346
Change-Id: Ic2599d594b627bd7ab584d1a314360921e41a203
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/30/146330/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from openstack_dashboard.dashboards.admin.networks.ports \ import tables as ports_tables from openstack_dashboard.dashboards.project.networks.ports \ import views as project_viewsclass DetailView(project_views.DetailView): def get_context_data(self, **kwargs): context = super(DetailView, self).get_context_data(**kwargs) port = context["port"] table = ports_tables.PortsTable(self.request, network_id=port.network_id) context["url"] = self.get_redirect_url() context["actions"] = table.render_row_actions(port) return context @staticmethod def get_redirect_url(): return reverse('horizon:admin:networks:index')

commit_message:
Removed lxc templates that are no longer used

This PR removes LXC templates that are no longer used in any context.
The templates were holdovers from when the upstream Ubuntu template
did not support additional packages in containers by default. The
issues within the default template have been removed and we should
change to using the default Ubuntu template immediately.

This template change should be backported to all applicable branches.
which would include both Icehouse and Juno.

Closes-Bug: #1437063

Change-Id: I4cece0fcfc1c3badb246726b7187452cb9d2ad83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/70/168170/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Cluster config for SSP disk driver

The SSP disk driver is going to need VIOS information in order to do
things like mapping LUs to LPARs.

The PowerVM SharedStoragePool object doesn't have Node (VIOS)
information, but the Cluster object does.

The Cluster object contains a reference to its corresponding
SharedStoragePool, but not vice versa.

So it makes more sense for the user to specify just the cluster name in
the configuration, and the SSP disk driver can discover the associated
SSP.

Change-Id: Ia7f88800eeeb1f576555fea777e2e4f8427ae808
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/79/167879/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pypowervm.wrappers.cluster as pvm_clust cfg.StrOpt('cluster_name', help='Cluster hosting the Shared Storage Pool to use for ' 'storage operations. If none specified, the host is ' 'queried; if a single Cluster is found, it is used.')class ClusterNotFoundByName(disk.AbstractDiskException): msg_fmt = _LE("Unable to locate the Cluster '%(clust_name)s' for this " "operation.") class NoConfigNoClusterFound(disk.AbstractDiskException): msg_fmt = _LE('Unable to locate any Cluster for this operation.') class TooManyClustersFound(disk.AbstractDiskException): msg_fmt = _LE("Unexpectedly found %(clust_count)d Clusters " "matching name '%(clust_name)s'.") class NoConfigTooManyClusters(disk.AbstractDiskException): msg_fmt = _LE("No cluster_name specified. Refusing to select one of the " "%(clust_count)d Clusters found.") self._clust_wrap = self._fetch_cluster(CONF.cluster_name) self.clust_name = self._clust_wrap.name # _ssp @property method will fetch the SSP and set self._ssp_wrap self.ssp_name = self._ssp.name LOG.info(_LI("SSP Storage driver initialized. " "Cluster '%(clust_name)s'; SSP '%(ssp_name)s'") % {'clust_name': self.clust_name, 'ssp_name': self.ssp_name}) return float(self._ssp.capacity) ssp = self._ssp def _fetch_cluster(self, clust_name): """Bootstrap fetch the Cluster associated with the configured name. The cluster_name from the config is used to perform a search query. If no cluster_name was specified in the config, we query all clusters on the host and, if exactly one is found, we use it. The Cluster EntryWrapper is 'cached' locally as self._clust_wrap. # Not yet loaded. # Did config provide a name? if clust_name: resp = pvm_clust.Cluster.search(self.adapter, name=clust_name) wraps = pvm_clust.Cluster.wrap(resp) if len(wraps) == 0: raise ClusterNotFoundByName(clust_name=clust_name) if len(wraps) > 1: raise TooManyClustersFound(clust_count=len(wraps), clust_name=clust_name) else: # Otherwise, pull the entire feed of Clusters and, if # exactly one result, use it. resp = self.adapter.read(pvm_clust.Cluster.schema_type) wraps = pvm_clust.Cluster.wrap(resp) if len(wraps) == 0: raise NoConfigNoClusterFound() if len(wraps) > 1: raise NoConfigTooManyClusters(clust_count=len(wraps)) clust_wrap = wraps[0] return clust_wrap def _refresh_cluster(self): """Refetch the Cluster from the host. This should be necessary only when the node list is needed and may have changed. :return: The refreshed self._clust_wrap. """ # TODO(IBM): If the Cluster doesn't exist when the driver is loaded, we # raise one of the custom exceptions; but if it gets removed at some # point while live, we'll (re)raise the 404 HttpError from the REST # API. Do we need a crisper way to distinguish these two scenarios? # Do we want to trap the 404 and raise a custom "ClusterVanished"? self._clust_wrap = self._clust_wrap.refresh(self.adapter) return self._clust_wrap @property def _ssp(self): """Fetch or refresh the SSP corresponding to the Cluster. This must be invoked after a successful _fetch_cluster. :return: The fetched or refreshed self._ssp_wrap. """ # TODO(IBM): Smarter refreshing (i.e. don't do it every time). if self._ssp_wrap is None: resp = self.adapter.read_by_href(self._clust_wrap.ssp_uri) self._ssp_wrap = pvm_stg.SSP.wrap(resp) else: self._ssp_wrap = self._ssp_wrap.refresh(self.adapter) @property def _vios_uuids(self): """Return a list of the UUIDs of our cluster's VIOSes.""" return [n.vios_uuid for n in self._clust_wrap.nodes]

Refusing to select one of the " "%(ssp_count)d Shared Storage Pools found.") # TODO(IBM) Query the VIOSes to find the one containing the SSP. # This is a temporary method to find the VIOS. vios_map = vios.get_vios_name_map(self.adapter, self.host_uuid) self.vios_name, self.vios_uuid = vios_map.items()[0] self.ssp_name = CONF.ssp_name # Make sure _fetch_ssp_wrap knows it has to bootstrap by name self._fetch_ssp_wrap() # Sets self._ssp_wrap LOG.info(_LI('SSP Storage driver initialized: ' 'SSP: \'%s\'') % self.ssp_name) ssp = self._fetch_ssp_wrap() return float(ssp.capacity) ssp = self._fetch_ssp_wrap() def _fetch_ssp_wrap(self): """Return the SSP EntryWrapper associated with the configured name. The SSP EntryWrapper is 'cached' locally. In a bootstrap scenario, the ssp_name from the config is used to perform a search query. Otherwise, the cached wrapper is refreshed. if self._ssp_wrap is None: # Not yet loaded. # Did config provide a name? if self.ssp_name: resp = pvm_stg.SSP.search(self.adapter, name=self.ssp_name) wraps = pvm_stg.SSP.wrap(resp) if len(wraps) == 0: raise SSPNotFoundByName(ssp_name=self.ssp_name) if len(wraps) > 1: raise TooManySSPsFound(ssp_count=len(wraps), ssp_name=self.ssp_name) else: # Otherwise, pull the entire feed of SSPs and, if exactly # one result, use it. resp = self.adapter.read(pvm_stg.SSP.schema_type) wraps = pvm_stg.SSP.wrap(resp) if len(wraps) == 0: raise NoConfigNoSSPFound() if len(wraps) > 1: raise NoConfigTooManySSPs(ssp_count=len(wraps)) self._ssp_wrap = wraps[0] self.ssp_name = self._ssp_wrap.name else: # Already loaded. Refresh. self._ssp_wrap = self._ssp_wrap.refresh(self.adapter) # TODO(IBM): If the SSP doesn't exist when the driver is loaded, we # raise one of the custom exceptions; but if it gets removed at some # point while live, we'll (re)raise the 404 HttpError from the REST # API. commit_message:
Allow baymodel name when bay is created

Bay needs baymodel id when bay is created. But usually, user want to use
`baymodel name` instead of baymodel id.
This patch supports baymodel name when bay is created.

Eg. magnum bay-create --name bay1 --baymodel baymodel-name

Partially implements blueprint name-based-resource-management

Change-Id: I1c2806faf906aa5f8cd1deef24136f04b63f954f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-magnumclient refs/changes/46/168246/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @utils.arg('--baymodel', metavar='<baymodel>', help='ID or name of the bay model.') baymodel = cs.baymodels.get(args.baymodel) opts['baymodel_id'] = baymodel.uuid
deleted_lines: @utils.arg('--baymodel-id', metavar='<baymodel_id>', help='The bay model ID.') opts['baymodel_id'] = args.baymodel_id

Partially implements blueprint name-based-resource-management

commit_message:
Add X-Container-Meta-Web-Directory-Type to Add container meta.

Change-Id: If4eb66643dda0595f405540f209560eea495432c
Closes-Bug: #1197655
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/00/168000/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Sets the content-type of directory marker objects. If the header is not set, default is application/directory. Directory marker objects are 0-byte objects that represent directories to create a simulated hierarchical structure. For example, if you set "X-Container-Meta-Web-Directory- Type: text/directory", Object Storage treats 0-byte objects with a content-type of text/directory as directories rather than objects. '>

commit_message:
Don't record time when self.timing is False

The expected behavior is when timing is True, then we record each
request's time, then we should call reset_timings() to release memory.

However, the shell, client.{HTTPClient,SessionClient} will record each
request's time no matter what timing is set, then after long running
time in service like ceilometer-agent-compute, the memory keeps increasing.

We'd better not record request's time when timing is set to False.
Users are not responiable to call reset_timings() when they don't want
timing functionality.

Change-Id: I3e7d2fadf9a21be018781d528a1b6562228da6dd
Closes-Bug: #1433491
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/43/165343/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.timings: self.times.append(("%s %s" % (method, url), start_time, time.time()))

commit_message:
Cue API list Clusters to include enpoints

Adding endpoints to Cue API list request.  Endpoints were
previously only returned in cluster get/show requests.  Since
endpoints are critical for the user, cluster list should show
respective endpoints for each cluster.

* tests have been updated to reflect this change

Note: Puthon-Cue-client will also have to be updated to reflect this change.

Partial-Bug: 1436114

commit_message:
Rename stackforge/magnum -> openstack/magnum

The TC voted to permit Magnum to enter the big tent.  This means the
Magnum project should be placed under the openstack namespace.
Also addressed python-magnumclient.

Depends-On: I1880a7310876c54bd5bd4bc16c6c5132c6ecb706
Change-Id: I5e672bafd8c7ec7eb7c0ec9df5a712bc0e097ccb

commit_message:
Add a Proxy for the Volume service

Add a Proxy for the Volume service and add the Volume service to the
UserPreferences to make it convenient to use.

Change-Id: I3507dfdfc8b44c51b83ae0d0eaa76c5f84c29fef

commit_message:
Use any instead of False in generator

any is both idiomatic and easier to read. There's no performance difference
because both will stop as soon as a matching value is found.

Change-Id: Ia527d96844015085cc289869a3c4d2722db1043c

commit_message:
Initialize vmware session during store creation

The vmware store instance is reusable, there is no need to
keep the vmware session object in the class data. This was earlier
done when multiple store instances shared the session object.

Change-Id: I856f7c743537326acc2a2bc9fed78ef473775f24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/08/164408/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def reset_session(self): self.session = api.VMwareAPISession( self.server_host, self.server_username, self.server_password, self.api_retry_count, self.tpoll_interval) return self.session self.session = self.reset_session() self.reset_session() self.reset_session()
deleted_lines: # FIXME(arnaud): re-visit this code once the store API is cleaned up. _VMW_SESSION = None def reset_session(self, force=False): if Store._VMW_SESSION is None or force: Store._VMW_SESSION = api.VMwareAPISession( self.server_host, self.server_username, self.server_password, self.api_retry_count, self.tpoll_interval) return Store._VMW_SESSION session = property(reset_session) self.reset_session(force=True) self.reset_session(force=True)

commit_message:
Move coobook-monasca-* to stackforge-attic

Monasca has moved to using Ansible instead of Chef so the
cookbook-monasca-* projects are no longer being maintained.

Also, update the channels to include all current monasca
projects.

Change-Id: I92bde20bab37b6511f7e96ff8ceede094c7e1b56

NetScaler driver for LBaaS V2 extension

Change-Id: I20b61f9d8027e6150cd39911251e5f1bcdc5d417
Implements: blueprint netscaler-lbass-v2-driver

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Citrix Systems # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from neutron import context from neutron import manager from neutron.plugins.common import constants from neutron.services.loadbalancer.drivers.netscaler import netscaler_driver_v2 from neutron.tests.unit.db.loadbalancer import test_db_loadbalancerv2 LBAAS_DRIVER_CLASS = ('neutron.services.loadbalancer.drivers' '.netscaler.netscaler_driver_v2' '.NetScalerLoadBalancerDriverV2') NCC_CLIENT_CLASS = ('neutron.services.loadbalancer.drivers' '.netscaler.ncc_client' '.NSClient') LBAAS_PROVIDER_NAME = 'netscaler' LBAAS_PROVIDER = 'LOADBALANCERV2:lbaas:' + LBAAS_DRIVER_CLASS + ':default' # Test data TESTLB_ID = '52ab5d71-6bb2-457f-8414-22a4ba55efec' TESTLISTENER_ID = '32ab5d71-6bb2-457f-8414-22a4ba55efec' TESTPOOL_ID = 'da477c13-24cd-4c9f-8c19-757a61ef3b9d' TESTMEMBER_ID = '84dea8bc-3416-4fb0-83f9-2ca6e7173bee' TESTMONITOR_ID = '9b9245a2-0413-4f15-87ef-9a41ef66048c' TESTVIP_PORT_ID = '327d9662-ade9-4c74-aaf6-c76f145c1180' TESTVIP_IP = '10.0.1.100' TESTMEMBER_IP = '10.0.0.5' class TestLoadBalancerPluginBase(test_db_loadbalancerv2 .LbaasPluginDbTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestLoadBalancerPluginBase, self).setUp( lbaas_provider=LBAAS_PROVIDER) loaded_plugins = manager.NeutronManager().get_service_plugins() self.plugin_instance = loaded_plugins[constants.LOADBALANCERV2] class TestNetScalerPluginDriverV2(TestLoadBalancerPluginBase): """Unit tests for the NetScaler LBaaS driver module.""" def setUp(self): mock.patch.object(netscaler_driver_v2, 'LOG').start() # mock the NSClient class (REST client) client_mock_cls = mock.patch(NCC_CLIENT_CLASS).start() # mock the REST methods of the NSClient class self.client_mock_instance = client_mock_cls.return_value self.create_resource_mock = self.client_mock_instance.create_resource self.create_resource_mock.side_effect = mock_create_resource_func self.update_resource_mock = self.client_mock_instance.update_resource self.update_resource_mock.side_effect = mock_update_resource_func self.retrieve_resource_mock = (self.client_mock_instance .retrieve_resource) self.retrieve_resource_mock.side_effect = mock_retrieve_resource_func self.remove_resource_mock = self.client_mock_instance.remove_resource self.remove_resource_mock.side_effect = mock_remove_resource_func super(TestNetScalerPluginDriverV2, self).setUp() self.plugin_instance.drivers[LBAAS_PROVIDER_NAME] = ( netscaler_driver_v2.NetScalerLoadBalancerDriverV2( self.plugin_instance)) self.driver = self.plugin_instance.drivers[LBAAS_PROVIDER_NAME] self.context = context.get_admin_context() def test_create_lb(self): with self.network() as network: with self.subnet(network=network) as subnet: # mock the LBaaS plugin update_status(). self._mock_update_status() # reset the create_resource() mock self.create_resource_mock.reset_mock() # execute the create method under test with self.loadbalancer(subnet=subnet, no_delete=True, provider=LBAAS_PROVIDER_NAME) as testlb: lb_id = testlb['loadbalancer']['id'] db_lb = self.plugin.db.get_loadbalancer( self.context, lb_id) expectedlb = self._build_expectedlb_contents( db_lb, subnet['subnet']) # First, assert that create_resource was called once # with expected params. resource_path = "%s/%s" % ( netscaler_driver_v2.RESOURCE_PREFIX, netscaler_driver_v2.LBS_RESOURCE) self.create_resource_mock.assert_called_once_with( None, resource_path, netscaler_driver_v2.LB_RESOURCE, expectedlb) # Finally, assert that the loadbalancer object is now # ACTIVE self.mock_update_status_obj.assert_called_once_with( mock.ANY, mock.ANY) args, kwargs = self.mock_update_status_obj.call_args loadbalancer_db_arg = args[1] self.assertEqual(str(loadbalancer_db_arg.id), str(lb_id)) def test_update_lb(self): with self.network(do_delete=False) as network: with self.subnet(network=network, do_delete=False) as subnet: with self.loadbalancer(subnet=subnet, no_delete=True, provider=LBAAS_PROVIDER_NAME) as lb: lb_id = lb['loadbalancer']['id'] testlb = self.\ _build_updated_testlb_contents(lb, subnet['subnet']) expectedlb = self._build_updated_expectedlb_contents( testlb['loadbalancer'], subnet['subnet']) # mock the LBaaS plugin update_status(). self._mock_update_status() # reset the update_resource() mock self.update_resource_mock.reset_mock() # execute the method under test self.new_update_request('loadbalancers', testlb, lb_id) # First, assert that create_resource was called once # with expected params. resource_path = "%s/%s/%s" % ( netscaler_driver_v2.RESOURCE_PREFIX, netscaler_driver_v2.LBS_RESOURCE, lb_id) self.update_resource_mock.assert_called_once_with( None, resource_path, netscaler_driver_v2.LB_RESOURCE, expectedlb) # Finally, assert that the vip object is now ACTIVE self.mock_update_status_obj.assert_called_once_with( mock.ANY, mock.ANY) args, kwargs = self.mock_update_status_obj.call_args loadbalancer_db_arg = args[1] self.assertEqual(str(loadbalancer_db_arg.id), str(lb_id)) def test_delete_lb(self): with self.network(do_delete=False) as network: with self.subnet(network=network, do_delete=False) as subnet: with self.loadbalancer(subnet=subnet, no_delete=True, provider=LBAAS_PROVIDER_NAME) as lb: lb_id = lb['loadbalancer']['id'] # reset the remove_resource() mock self.remove_resource_mock.reset_mock() self.new_delete_request('loadbalancers', lb_id) resource_path = "%s/%s/%s" % ( netscaler_driver_v2.RESOURCE_PREFIX, netscaler_driver_v2.LBS_RESOURCE, lb_id) self.remove_resource_mock.assert_called_once_with( None, resource_path) def _build_testlb_contents(self, subnet): lb_obj = dict(id=TESTLB_ID, tenant_id=self._tenant_id, name='testlb', description='a test lb', vip_subnet_id=subnet['id'], vip_port_id=TESTVIP_PORT_ID, vip_address=TESTVIP_IP, admin_state_up=True, status='PENDING_CREATE', status_description='') return lb_obj def _build_expectedlb_contents(self, testlb, subnet): expectedlb = dict(id=testlb.id, name=testlb.name, description=testlb.description, tenant_id=testlb.tenant_id, vip_port_id=testlb.vip_port_id, vip_address=testlb.vip_address, subnet_id=testlb.vip_subnet_id, network_id=subnet['network_id'], admin_state_up=testlb.admin_state_up) return expectedlb def _build_updated_testlb_contents(self, testlb, subnet): # update some updateable fields of the lb updated_lb = dict() updated_lb['name'] = 'udpated testlb' updated_lb['description'] = 'An updated version of test vip' updated_lb['admin_state_up'] = True return {'loadbalancer': updated_lb} def _build_updated_expectedlb_contents(self, testlb, subnet): expectedlb = dict(name=testlb['name'], description=testlb['description'], admin_state_up=testlb['admin_state_up']) return expectedlb def _mock_update_status(self): # patch the plugin's activate_linked_entities() method with a mock obj self.mock_update_status_patcher = mock.patch.object( self.driver.plugin, 'activate_linked_entities') self.mock_update_status_obj = self.mock_update_status_patcher.start() def mock_create_resource_func(*args, **kwargs): return 201, {} def mock_update_resource_func(*args, **kwargs): return 202, {} def mock_retrieve_resource_func(*args, **kwargs): return 200, {} def mock_remove_resource_func(*args, **kwargs): return 200, {}

commit_message:
VMWare Edge loadbalancer v1 driver

Adds support for VMWare NSX-v Edge loadbalancer appliance.
The support is for lbaasv1 API.

Change-Id: I6f65aa053fd131e0b17757fda1a483c6f5a25a11
Partially-Implements: blueprint vmware-nsx-v

commit_message:
Move os-client-config from Stackforge to OpenStack

Recently it was included in the python-openstackclient project, so when
we do renames, we should rename it.

Depends-On: Ie6c0997d47ac0a1ed6bda54a67233b019c13b84e
Change-Id: I58c2280511c29b6235cd03ffaf05ecd8685a545e

commit_message:
Rename fuel-tasks-validator to fuel-tasklib

Scope of the initial project has been increased greatly and current
name need to be change to avoid confusion and mistakes.

Change-Id: Ie8b46b617db82a326c80083348e1551bc274c4d9

commit_message:
Non-admin token tests for Keystone API

Adds non-admin token tests for Keystone/identity API. Work in
support of adding Defcore/interop capabilities for identity.

Currently only supports get token for v2 and v3.

Depends-On: I06fd043e1b31ae0e5e33f4dcf898fb58f2907267
Change-Id: I2134e5694fdbab13b4b19205ecba5711dbac0c25

commit_message:
Removed lxc templates that are no longer used (juno)

This PR removes LXC templates that are no longer used in any context.
The templates were holdovers from when the upstream Ubuntu template
did not support additional packages in containers by default. The
issues within the default template have been removed and we should
change to using the default Ubuntu template immediately.

This template change should be backported to all applicable branches.
which would include both Icehouse and Juno.

Closes-Bug: #1437063
(cherry picked from commit 5cc205ccfc26973b378aae7709c12ab58498d87b)

Change-Id: I9eed1b37369b8eee52584a5e6ee51a0f2cabe963

commit_message:
Added the missing attachment to detach_volume

I must have missed this driver in the multiattach
patch. The attachment object is passed in to
detach_volume to give drivers a chance to deal with
a detach call.

This patch just updates the signature of the method
to be the same as the parent.

Change-Id: Id881ea67fbe7434d83a12dc0c5b04b512aa2ec1e
Closes-Bug: #1436367
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/66/168266/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Rename stackforge/bindep -> openstack-infra/bindep

This patch brings the stackforge/bindep repository under the
openstack-infra namespace.

The bindep-core gerrit group is preserved, infra-core will be
added to that group. A new bindep-release gerrit group is
created.

Depends-on: I94b4c119f46cd6d6b607f5abc394a63fb2b0b97f
Change-Id: I39309976c2d0c05bbcfa88dc0928547e34cc4e6e

commit_message:
Fixes plugin.ini error

When executing the cisco.pp manifest it throws an error
if the plugin.ini file is already declared.

I know this plugin will be deprecated in juno but this change
is needed for icehouse.

Change-Id: I9b8efe668911013d4fd801def15d0c4c384e42ca
